Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating the mechanism of phonological change in progress: Allophonic restructuring of /ae/ in Philadelphia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this dissertation project is to deepen our understanding of how language change spreads through a speech community. Language change is a constant and inevitable fact about language: new words, new sound patterns, new syntactic constructions. Because large-scale sound recordings are relatively new, very little is understood about the production and mental representation of sound changes in the minds of individuals who acquire language during a period of phonological change. This project investigates a phonological restructuring currently in progress in Philadelphia, in order to identify the mechanism of phonological change as it propagates through individual speakers in a speech community. The results will form the basis of a science fair exhibit on phonological change in Philadelphia, educating the public on language change and emphasizing the value of linguistic diversity.

Phonological change is defined as a change in the abstract representation or allophonic rules governing a phonological segment, to the exclusion of phonetic change, which entails a change in the physical output of a phonological segment. Previous hypotheses have suggested that phonological change occurs as the result of phonetic incrementation (Ohala, 1981), occurs before any phonetic incrementation (Fruehwald, 2013; Janda and Joseph 2003), or through an extension of competing grammars (Kroch, 1989; 2001) to phonological change (Fruehwald et al. 2013). The restructuring of short-a in Philadelphia provides an ideal testing ground for these three theories of phonological change, as it is an ongoing change allowing access to the critical speakers, and as the outputs of both systems provide clear evidence regarding the underlying system. Understanding the mechanism of phonological change within individuals will shed light on the mental representations of language change more broadly. Preliminary findings suggest the operation of two phonological subsystems of short-a within a single speaker, supporting the extension of competing grammars to phonological change and suggesting that categorical linguistic change in both the syntactic and phonological domain may occur through a period of grammar competition within individual speakers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Languages are constantly changing. Between one generation and the next, sound changes occur, resulting in differences in pronunciation over time. The most disruptive type of sound change that can occur is a phonological change, which not only results in a change in pronunciation but also a change in how speakers mentally represent the sounds of their language. The major goal of this dissertation is to determine how community-level phonological change is produced and represented by the individual speakers that make up that community.

Phonological change is difficult to analyze in real time, since it occurs suddenly, and typically over the span of just a single generation, which makes it difficult for researchers to capture data spanning the full length of the change. Furthermore, the three major theories about individual speakers’ behavior during phonological change (phonetic incrementation, Ohala (1981); instant phonologization, Janda and Josef (2013); and competition, Fruehwald et al. (2013), Kroch (1989)) are difficult to actually test, since most phonological changes involve mergers or splits, making individual tokens impossible to classify for underlying phonological system.

In this dissertation, I closely analyze speakers who acquired language during an allophonic restructuring of /æ/ in Philadelphia English. This allophonic restructuring is a phonological change which allows us to identify which of the three major theories of phonological change are at play. Through a combination of community-wide corpus analysis, targeted interviews with individual speakers, experimental evaluation techniques, and computational simulations, I present an analysis of the sociolinguistic and phonological mechanisms of a phonological change in Philadelphia English. I find that the transition cohort speakers produce wholesale variation between the old allophonic system and the new allophonic system, providing the first real-time evidence that phonological change occurs via intraspeaker competition, suggesting that phonological change and syntactic change proceed via the same mechanism in a speech community. In addition to the major finding described above, this dissertation also uses the Tolerance Principle (Yang, 2016) to provide a method of determining whether a given sound change is likely to be the result of endogenous innovation by children acquiring the language or the result of dialect contact with in-moving speakers of another dialect.

These results provide exciting directions for future sociolinguistic work in phonological change. First, the finding that phonological subsystems may act as a sociolinguistic variable for individual speakers invites future work in systemic variables from other speech communities. Additionally, the specific predictions generated by applying the Tolerance Principle to phonology can and should be tested both experimentally as well as in different changes from different speech communities. Finally, this dissertation demonstrates the importance of bringing the full suite of sociolinguistic and phonological facts, both on the macro-social (community) and micro-social (individuals and subsets of the community), to questions about sound change.
